Yes. Always.  How? There is famous saying which is true also: "Bhagvan ke ghar der hai andher nahi" (In God's home is delay but not disappointment) So is it possible that whatever we are asking is on the way. Only problem is our preference changes so dynamically that by the time our desired things come to us we no longer need that :)  For example, cell phone which I eagerly desired last year is not much desired at present. And today whichever cell phone I desire would not be case after a year Now if that is the case then question arises why would I ask for misery which I am experiencing?To answer that let us read below story this eventually is fact of life. A girl loves one boy and marries him. She is so happy. Boy is billionaire, big flat, big cars and everything. Only problem is time. He is so busy in his business that he hardly used to give time to his wife. She got all the facilities around her but husband used to go early and come late night &  she has to eat lunch and dinner alone  as only both of them were living in the house. Gradually she became unhappy with her current lifestyle despite for years she wanted such things around her.  One afternoon she was standing in her balcony and she saw that one worker has just finished his task, he sat beside road and started waiting for someone. After sometime his wife comes and both of them start having lunch together, they were teasing each other and having nice time together. She was watching all these and started thinking that "This is true happiness, they don’t have money and food is also not that much great but still they are together and having nice time with each other I wish I had such a life." There comes God who grants all our wishes and so her wish is noted down. After considering her good conducting in this birth, she destined to get such life in her next birth where she would enjoy the company of her husband as she desired. Meanwhile wife of the worker saw her standing in balcony and felt cool breeze which was flowing and was thinking that "How happy she must be. We are here with such an old clothes, not much money, not so good food and she is right on top, with superb flat, big cars!! wow how happy she must be I wish I had such a life" Once again God comes to picture and thanks to her good conducting in this birth she is destined to get her next life of what she desired at present. Now then on next birth their position got interchanged and the same play goes on and on. Perhaps same thing is going with us as well?We always say 'Grass is green on other side' but then once we go there we have our new preferences. If that is the case then why to blame God? He is simply giving us what we are desiring and asking. Then question comes why he delays things as being God he should grant at that moment only. Isn’t it ? Naah that would ruin our life. Imagine if you get whatever you want within a second will it be fun? It could be for few minutes but then there is no spark in life, there is sense of achievement in life and without which life would be like food without salt. We would feel that everything is there but something is missing. So we must truth God, the way he has designed this beautiful world which is working in a perfect and precise way. Beauty of life is that we can decide what we want; only thing is we must find right path, right way to live the life, stabiles our intellect, get control over our dynamic and changing desire and with the help of that increase the will power to win over any situation.  The controlled mind is a great treasure, the philosopher's stone, which yields whatever you want. – Swami Vivekananda

No. God gives us what *he* wants us to have, but only when we are willing to accept it (that pesky free will thing again: God cannot give what we refuse to accept). Now, if our “want” corresponds with God’s design and will, then sure, we’ll get it. Even Jesus did not get what he wanted from God: Matthew 6:29 - Going a little farther, he fell with his face to the ground and prayed, "My Father, if it is possible, may this cup be taken from me. Yet not as I will, but as you will." Two things of note in this passage: Jesus says what he wants, but places his wants as secondary to God’s will. This is the pattern for Christian prayer, and it is in this passage that we can see clearly one of the three logical fallacies embedded in Dick Hartfield’s answer. In short, prayer is not a tool we use to control God. It is a way of communicating our willingness to submit to God’s perfect and absolute authority, accept his gift of grace, and to open ourselves up to the inspiration of the Holy Spirit.

God is not our personal butler or servant. He does not answer all our prayers. Why? Because we are supposed to follow His will, not God following our will. Life is not a bed of roses, even if you try to be good, change, and follow God. Not everything I pray for and desire goes my way. But that is good - those difficulties tried and tested my trust in God. Will I act like a spoiled brat or will I continue to trust God in everything in my life? Will I be childish in following God, or grow in maturity to fully entrust my life, my plans, and my decision to Jesus my Lord? But even if I don’t get my way all or even most of the time, life is good. And we know that for those who love God all things work together for good, for those who are called according to his purpose. (Romans 8:28 ESV)
